newsitem.title: USA: Senator seeks fair review of Boeing merger.
newsitem.headline: Senator seeks fair review of Boeing merger.

text.p: Sen. Slade Gorton Thursday urged President Clinton to press the European Commission for an impartial review of the pending Boeing-McDonnell Douglas merger.

Gorton, Republican of Washington state, said he feared recent comments by EC member Karl Van Miert indicated a bias against the merger. He quoted Van Miert as saying if the merger were approved, it would leave Boeing and Airbus as the only competitors for passenger aircraft with Boeing able to win all the contracts because it has a full range of models while Airbus has only a partial range.

"We urge you to communicate U.S. expectations of due process and impartial review of the pending merger to the European Commission at the earliest possible time," Gorton said in his letter to Clinton.
He said Sen. Patty Murray, D-Washington state and other senators would also sign the letter.

Gorton said if the EC finds the Boeing merger anti-competitive, Boeing could be fined up to 10 percent of its sales. Boeing currently has 60 percent of the market share for commercial aircraft in Europe.
